subSections.title: Glyph origin
subSections.text:
{{Han etym}}
{{Han compound|立|占|c1=s|c2=p|ls=psc}}. A relatively late character – not found in ''{{w|Shuowen}}''; found in ''{{w|Guangyun}}''.

subSections.title: Etymology 1
subSections.text:
; “to stand”
: A Northern Chinese word attested since the 9-10th centuries. Displaced earlier {{zh-l|立}} in most modern northern Chinese varieties.

subSections.title: Definitions
Etymology 2
subSections.text:
Generally considered to be a Mongolian influence in the {{w|Yuan Dynasty}} – an abbreviation of {{zh-l|站赤|post stations during the Yuan Dynasty}}, from {{der|zh|xng|ᠵᠠᠮᠴᠢ||post station}} (> {{cog|mn|замч||guide; cicerone}}), a derivative of {{der|zh|xng|ᠵᠠᠮ||way, path}} (> {{cog|mn|зам}}).

Mongolian ''ǰam'' is undoubtedly cognate with {{cog|trk-pro|*jam||post station}} (> {{cog|tr|yam}}; ~ {{cog|ru|ям}}) with the same meaning; see {{w|Yam (route)}}. Starostin considers the Turkic form a descendant of Altaic *''ńi̯àmi'' ("trace") and related to Proto-Mongolian *''ǯim'' ("path, trace"; > {{cog|mn|ᠵᠢᠮ}} / {{l|mn|жим}}). Also compare {{cog|tr|yamçı||post rider}}, {{cog|ru|ямщи́к||drive, coachman}}.

There is no scholarly consensus regarding the direction of borrowing. Generally it is believed that Turkic ''jam'' and Chinese ''zhàn'' are loanwords from Mongolian ''ǰam'', however some (e.g. Tuymebayev in {{lang|ru|Казахско-монгольские лексические параллели}}) believe the directionality is reversed (i.e. Chinese "to stand > stand > station" → Middle Mongolian → Turkic → Russian). Whatever the etymology, what is apparent is that the word ''jam'' has been around for a long time and was used by Central Asians to designate a key postal relay station or official.

In Chinese, this word has been competing with the native equivalent {{zh-l|*驛|tr=yì|post station}} since its introduction. Mongol-ruled Yuan Dynasty saw a profusion of usages of ''zhàn'', which was deliberately suppressed in the succeeding {{w|Ming Dynasty}} in favour of ''yì''. Both were used in the subsequent {{w|Qing Dynasty}}, with ''zhàn'' eventually predominating in the modern times, being used to render the sense of "station" in modern concepts, such as "train station". Other Sinosphere countries show preference variations too: Vietnamese uses {{lang|zh|站}} ({{m|vi|trạm}}), whereas Japanese and Korean still use {{lang|zh|驛}} for "station" (Japanese {{ja-l|駅|えき|eki}}, Korean {{ko-l|역|驛}}).
